title: Adding structured documentation to Dat
abstract: 3 part: Presentation, workshop and planning-group-meeting with the goal to bring structured documentation to JavaScript packages.
description:
Structured documentation have found in different ways a place in the javascript ecosystem. Be it jsdoc, flow-type or typescript definition files: structured documentation is helpful in the exploration of a project (particularly options) to people outside of the project. Both martin and sam have been working on hyper* definition files and in Hyperswarm we have a discussion open on how to add TypeScript definition files [#55](https://github.com/hyperswarm/hyperswarm/issues/55#issuecomment-607318923) that haven't found their way in the project yet.

First we will have a short ~20min presentation on important things  we learned about writing definitions files, followed by a 1h workshop to add declaration to a project and in a follow-up step we want to discuss how we can bring this practically to the whole system.
byLine: by Sam Macbeth and Martin Heidegger

title: Inclusive indexing of research outputs through decentralized web
abstract: The primary goal of this facilitated discussion is to spark conversations and thoughts on the ways new knowledge is currently indexed, searched and integrated.
description:
The currently available indexing services are based on peer-reviewed journal articles (Medline, Scopus etc), preprint focused (Prepubmed) or text based (Google Scholar, Microsoft Academic). Such indexing excludes the visibility of other non-traditional outputs such as data sets and figures, and at times peer-reviewed articles from select fields and indigenous communities. Academic status quo practices act as gatekeeper of knowledge by ranking research outputs as well as deciding which forms of knowledge become valid. 

Intersectional approach will be used to refine an idea for a community owned platform to capture and search traditional as well as non-traditional research outputs with a persistent digital identifier.

title: The p2pcommons: A distributed information layer for research
abstract: The peer-to-peer commons (p2pcommons) is a set of standards for Hyperdrives to improve information sharing, especially in scholarly research. In this short presentation, I will introduce the core concepts of the p2pcommons (e.g., provenance, modules), why it is relevant for scholarly research, and I highlight some of the libraries we provide to develop software utilising the p2pcommons.

title: Holistic Digital Authorship
abstract: This collaborative workshop prompts discussion around precarious and hidden labour in digital authorship and open source development. Through conversations and drawings, we will explore tensions between social purpose vs. free labour, and our atomization in a competitive content market as creators.
description:
Inspired by Holistic Security by Tactical Tech and the Revolutionary Networked Politics presentations at transmediale, we will engage through a holistic approach that centres on self-care and the well-being of content authors. There are many topics relevant to digital publishing, such as: equitable compensations and dignified livelihoods, creative expression on moderated platforms, security and anonymity in online spaces. How does one navigate the complex environments and entrenched power structures of the Web? What is the cost of the labour asked of an individual creator and the impact on their well-being?

As an initiative of the Distributed Press project, and inspired by a surrealist parlour game, we will assemble the words and images generated during our workshop to compose a work of collective authorship to express our aspirations for the future web.
byLine: by Mai Ishikawa Sutton and Udit Vira

title: Introducing Idili: A Portable Personal Data Store
abstract: Idili is a personal data storage and social sharing platform, run on a portable computer such as a Rasberry Pi. The plan is to use dat/hypercore for decentralized identity management and to find a way to use it for data sharing purposes at least in part.
description:
Idili is just reaching a minimal viable product point and I'm looking forward to introducing it to people and finding collaborators.

The current codebase is available at https://git.sr.ht/~rschulman/idili

title: 'Digital Sovereignty' huh?
abstract: Sovereignty is popping up over the P2P space. But what do we mean by it? Some views and research emerging from cobox.cloud. co-presented with Jaya Klara Brekke (@jayapapaya) and Dan Hassan (@dan_mi_sun)
description:
'Digital sovereignty' huh?

Lately, states have been calling for it, start-ups have been pitching with it, and communities have been building for it. 

...but do we all mean the same thing? 

and what is some of the historical baggage that the term 'sovereignty' brings with it?
byLine: by Dan Hassan and Jaya Klara Brekke

title: Building a P2P Web (with Dat!)
abstract: The developer of the Gateway mobile browser will be discussing the process of building a fully p2p web. First by breaking down the current internet environment and its larger physical context, then exploring how we can sustain the potential change in power that p2p projects like dat have introduced.
description: The developer of the Gateway mobile browser will be discussing the process of building a fully p2p web. First by breaking down the current internet environment and its larger physical context, then exploring how we can sustain the potential change in power that p2p projects like dat have introduced.

title: Hypercores mapped to IPLD
abstract: The Hypercore data structure is built on top of a Merkle tree, and can be represented as a DAG - Directed Acyclic Graph. In this presentation, we will describe the data structure, and show how to construct a representation using the IPLD (Interplanetary Linked Data) library that is used by IPFS and Filecoin (also works standalone). Finally, we will show how to implement a storage provider that retrieves hypercore data from an IPLD-based datastore.

title: Making stuff with Dat-SDK
abstract: This workshop will take people through building a simple app with the Dat SDK and making it work in the command line and on a web page.

title: Hypercore Protocol in Rust
abstract: First I'll talk a bit about the state of #datrs, then I'll go into how I went about implementing Hypercore Protocol in Rust: What are the challenges, what is the current state of things? Afterwards I want to have a discussion on how to move forward with #datrs.

title: The Latest in Beaker Land
abstract: A quick overview of the Beaker's current status, what's new, and what's coming
byLine: by Paul Frazee and Andrew Osheroff

title: Using Dat & the Hyper Stack in Agroecology
abstract: Regenerative Agriculture, Agroecology, Conservation Ecology, and Urban Resilience increasingly make use of off-grid technologies; I'd like to review some of the ways in which Dat / Hyper and a 'local first' approach might be used in these contexts, with a particular focus on farming.  More description of these projects in general at https://edgecollective.io/

title: Cabal's Subjective Moderation System
abstract: People from Cabal, a peer-to-peer group chat, would like to present what we've done with our subjective moderation system with a live demonstration. The demonstration will be followed by a small Q&A around Cabal and our learnings from the moderation development process
description:
Nick and cblgh from Cabal will have a live workshop and introduction to Cabal's basics. After the basics, the subjective moderation system will be outlined and shown.

Participants that are eager to try things out live are invited to download one of Cabal's clients before the presentation:

**Cabal Desktop**
- mac: `brew cask install cabal`
- linux/windows: [https://github.com/cabal-club/cabal-desktop/releases/](https://github.com/cabal-club/cabal-desktop/releases/)

**Cabal's terminal client**
- `npm i -g cabal`

title: DatDot - how do can we host hypercores peer-to-peer
abstract: A walk through the DatDot project - from the concept for p2p hosting, through the technology behind it and its biggest challenges.
description:
DatDot is a Distributed (peer-to-peer ) Hosting Network.

https://datdot.org/#doc
byLine: by Nina Breznik and Alexander Praetorius

title: State of Hyper
abstract: I'll (mafintosh) will give an overview on where things are technically with the Hypercore Protocol, where it's going etc.

title: Funding Opportunities in Europe
abstract: An overview over the open calls in the Next Generation Internet, manufacturing, artificial intelligence and more. For projects in need of funding.
description:
The mission of FundingBox is to connect creative minds with the right business opportunities in Europe. As such I would like to share with you insight into the open calls we manage as well as into other funding initiatives

Discover through this session public funding opportunities from the European Commission in several fields: manufacturing, robotics, automation, Next Generation Internet, artificial intelligence, EdTech, and more. We will also explore benefits beyond funding: acceleration, training and mentoring from experts, internationalisation, networking and more.
byLine: by David Seoane and Pablo Mondragón Fernández

title: Introduction to Agregore - a minimal P2P web browser
abstract: This talk will introduce a new web browser, Agregore, and it's ideas about leveraging HTTP-like semantics to bring p2p protocols to the web.
description: This talk will go over Agregore, why it was built, how it works, it's goals, and the ideas behind using `fetch()` interfaces for peer to peer protocols.

title: Building a network library
abstract: Libraries provide a way for knowledge to be structured and made available to all.  As datasets become as important as books how will a library make it possible to find all the datasets?  We will present and demo an implementation of a network library using hypertrie.
description: Librarians invented ways to describe knowledge, initially for books and manuscript and created structures to describe the content that are shared openly.  In a digital age libraries need to structure knowledge of images, video, code and datasets etc.  These come from many authors and on a daily volume hard for humans to keep pace with.  Inspired by projects like https://www.researchobject.org/  how would such thinking work on peer to peer infrastructure?    We will demonstrate working code of a network library ( https://youtu.be/N-Ak9mvmZZM )  that creates a set of 'smart' reference contracts that describe datatypes, computations, visualizations and modules that allow for the creation of network experiments.
byLine: by James Littlejohn and Denis Parfenov

title: Changing to "Hyper" and the future of the Dat ecosystem
abstract: This year, we renamed the Dat protocol to the Hypercore protocol. In this talk, we'll review what's changed and what the future holds for the Dat ecosystem.

title: The Dat Universe - Interoperability discussion
abstract:
How do different projects use Hypercores? How can the work with each other?

In this session we will try to give a quick overview of how the different projects in the community make use of Hypercores. We'll quickly talk about Multifeed, Hyperdrive, Corestore, Kappa Core and how these modules differ in their approach to feed and network management - and how projects like Beaker, Cabal, Cobox, DatDot, Sonar and others use them.

Then, for the main part of this session, we will moderate a discussion on different topics of interoperability and possible future collaboration points. Please feel very invited to join this discussion, both with ideas and questions on how the ecosystem could develop.
byLine: by Franz Heinzmann and Nina Breznik
